material_source_passage: Tungsten oxide (WO<sub>3</sub>) is widely used in industry, as catalyst and catalytic support<sup>1-3</sup>. Intrinsic and/or extrinsic defects can tune the compound's behavior, in particular the electrical and optical properties, leading to electrochromic and gasochromic applications as well as to potential in areas such as smart windows, gas sensors and optoelectonics<sup>4-7</sup>. Stoichiometric WO<sub>3</sub> is transparent and insulating with a band gap of 3.0 eV to 3.3 eV<sup>8,9</sup>, while presence of O vacancies results in optical absorption (blue color due to gap narrowing) and electrical conductivity<sup>10,11</sup>
property_source_passage: Tungsten oxide (WO<sub>3</sub>) is widely used in industry, as catalyst and catalytic support<sup>1-3</sup>. Intrinsic and/or extrinsic defects can tune the compound's behavior, in particular the electrical and optical properties, leading to electrochromic and gasochromic applications as well as to potential in areas such as smart windows, gas sensors and optoelectonics<sup>4-7</sup>. Stoichiometric WO<sub>3</sub> is transparent and insulating with a band gap of 3.0 eV to 3.3 eV<sup>8,9</sup>, while presence of O vacancies results in optical absorption (blue color due to gap narrowing) and electrical conductivity<sup>10,11</sup>
value_source_passage: Tungsten oxide (WO<sub>3</sub>) is widely used in industry, as catalyst and catalytic support<sup>1-3</sup>. Intrinsic and/or extrinsic defects can tune the compound's behavior, in particular the electrical and optical properties, leading to electrochromic and gasochromic applications as well as to potential in areas such as smart windows, gas sensors and optoelectonics<sup>4-7</sup>. Stoichiometric WO<sub>3</sub> is transparent and insulating with a band gap of 3.0 eV to 3.3 eV<sup>8,9</sup>, while presence of O vacancies results in optical absorption (blue color due to gap narrowing) and electrical conductivity<sup>10,11</sup>

material_source_passage: The lattice constants of <ital>γ</ital>-monoclinic WO<sub>3</sub> are calculated to be <ital>a</ital>=7.27 Å, <ital>b</ital>=7.36 Å, and <ital>c</ital>=7.54 Å, which agrees reasonably well with the experimental values (<ital>a</ital>= 7.31 Å, <ital>b</ital>= 7.54 Å, and <ital>c</ital>= 7.69 Å) and previous theoretical results (<ital>a</ital>=7.39 Å, <ital>b</ital>=7.64 Å, and <ital>c</ital>=7.75 Å)<sup>18</sup>.

material_source_passage: Furthermore, the UV-vis adsorption spectra in Fig. 6(b) demonstrate energy gaps of 3.0 eV, 2.8 eV, and 2.75 eV for WO<sub>3</sub>, WO<sub>3−<ital>x</ital></sub>, and H<sub><ital>z</ital></sub>WO<sub>3−<ital>x</ital></sub>, respectively. The UPS spectra in Fig. 7 show for WO<sub>3</sub> the valence band maximum 2.9 ± 0.1 eV below the Fermi level, reflecting an n-type semiconductor, consistent with earlier experiments<sup>23</sup>. WO<sub>3−<ital>x</ital></sub><ital> </ital>and H<sub><ital>z</ital></sub>WO<sub>3−<ital>x</ital></sub><ital> </ital>exhibit similar valence band onsets. The main difference between the three oxides is related to the secondary electron cut-off region from which the work function can be estimated. We obtain values of 5.2 eV for WO<sub>3</sub>, WO<sub>3−<ital>x</ital></sub><ital> </ital>and 5.6 eV for H<sub><ital>z</ital></sub>WO<sub>3−<ital>x</ital></sub>. The work function of H<sub><ital>z</ital></sub>WO<sub>3−<ital>x</ital></sub><ital> </ital>thus agrees with that of fresh tungsten oxide samples<sup>27,28</sup>, while the lower values of WO<sub>3 </sub>and WO<sub>3−<ital>x</ital></sub><ital> </ital>can be explained by hygroscopic water uptake that occurs instantaneously in air and reduces the work function<sup>29</sup>

WO<sub>3−<ital>x</ital></sub><ital> </ital>and H<sub><ital>z</ital></sub>WO<sub>3−<ital>x</ital></sub><ital> </ital>exhibit similar valence band onsets. The main difference between the three oxides is related to the secondary electron cut-off region from which the work function can be estimated. We obtain values of 5.2 eV for WO<sub>3</sub>, WO<sub>3−<ital>x</ital></sub><ital> </ital>and 5.6 eV for H<sub><ital>z</ital></sub>WO<sub>3−<ital>x</ital></sub>. The work function of H<sub><ital>z</ital></sub>WO<sub>3−<ital>x</ital></sub><ital> </ital>thus agrees with that of fresh tungsten oxide samples<sup>27,28</sup>, while the lower values of WO<sub>3 </sub>and WO<sub>3−<ital>x</ital></sub><ital> </ital>can be explained by hygroscopic water uptake that occurs instantaneously in air and reduces the work function<sup>29</sup>.
